Award.AwardTitle: Hazards TEAMS: Teacher Education & Activities for Minority Students in the Meteorological, Geologic and Hydrologic Hazards. TRACK 1
Award.AbstractNarration: The Mississippi State University Geosciences and Civil and Environmental Engineering programs are collaborating to provide learning experiences for both K-12 teachers and students in geology, meteorology and hydrology under the common theme of natural hazards. The Hazards TEAMS project has 4 goals: 1) to increase K-12 teachers' Earth Science content knowledge, 2) to increase students' knowledge of geoscience careers and the path needed to obtain them, 3) to increase student interest in geosciences through engaging lessons in the classroom and fun hands-on activities at Mississippi State University (MSU), and 4) to better enable guidance counselors to direct students into geoscience majors and career paths. The project team is providing a hazards-related workshop for 8-10 "Partner Teachers" from high-minority Mississippi school districts, as well as the Mississippi Migrant Student Education Center. During the following year, these partner teachers lead a similar workshop for a second group of teachers. Middle and junior high school students are gaining knowledge about the geosciences through activity days and a summer camp on the MSU campus as well as through materials and lessons the teachers are able to bring into the classroom. The activity days and summer camp are increasing student interest in the geosciences as well as exposing middle or junior high school students to a college campus and laboratories. They are also exposing younger students to individuals currently enrolled in majors leading to careers in the geosciences who may serve as role models. The focus on increasing students' knowledge of careers and college majors available in the geosciences is also addressed through designed brochures that are mailed to guidance counselors throughout the state. Prior to the creation of the brochure, guidance counselors are surveyed to determine their awareness of the careers and education pathways available in the geosciences, as well the coursework and activities students can take advantage of to increase their chance of success in entering and completing a geoscience major.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project had five goals: 1) to increase K-12 teacher’s Earth Science content knowledge, 2) to expose middle or junior high school students to a college campus and laboratories, 3) to increase students’ knowledge of Geosciences careers and the path needed to obtain them, 4) to increase student interest in Geosciences through engaging lessons in the classroom and fun hands-on activities at MSU, and 5)     to expose these students to individuals with whom they can relate who are currently enrolled in majors such as Geosciences or Civil and Environmental Engineering that can lead to careers in the geosciences. This project significantly increased the capacity of teachers across the state of Mississippi to teach Earth Science topics by inviting them to participate in a series of workshops focusing on Earth Hazards. Our results indicate that regardless of the teachers’ starting point, each workshop class gained knowledge and confidence about geology, meteorology and hydrology.  This includes both content as well as career-related knowledge. Overall, we provided professional development to 60 teachers. Thus, we have increased the Earth Science knowledge of 60 Mississippi K-12 teachers. Many of these teachers were able to take activities back to their classrooms to help increase their students’ interest in the geosciences. Additionally, we brought 10 students to the university campus to attend an Earth Hazards summer camp. Eight out of the 10 students were African American, which is important because the field of geosciences has experienced difficulty in recruiting members of underrepresented minority groups to its majors and careers.   All of the camp participants reported that they would want to return if the camp was offered again, indicating its success in associating the geosciences with fun and interesting activities. Tests completed by the campers before and after the camp showed that they gained new career knowledge about the geosciences.  They also improved their knowledge of geology. Approximately 30 middle school students were also exposed to the MSU campus, laboratories and students during a fall activity day.  The students were very favorable about their experiences at the activity day. They enjoyed the visit to MSU, and also expressed interest in the Geosciences and related careers. Based on evaluation of the teacher workshops as well as the student activities, hazards provides an effective means to increase teachers’ content knowledge about Earth Science and raise awareness of geoscience careers and majors.
